evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: On June 18, 2025, petitioner Osorto was waiting with others, including co-petitioners Pedro Vasquez Pedermo and Issac Antonio Villegas Molina, at a Pasadena, California bus stop to be picked up for a job.

extracted.value: On June 18, 2025, petitioner Osorto was waiting with others at a Pasadena, California bus stop to be picked up for a job.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: When petitioner saw federal agents approach, he tried to run but stopped when an agent pointed a taser at his head and said, “stop or I’ll use it.”

extracted.value: When petitioner saw federal agents approach, he tried to run but stopped when an agent pointed a taser at his head and said, “stop or I’ll use it.”

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: Federal agents then handcuffed petitioner and put him in a vehicle.

extracted.value: Federal agents handcuffed petitioner and put him in a vehicle.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: The federal agents brought petitioner to a nearby CVS parking lot and then asked him if he had papers.

extracted.value: The federal agents brought petitioner to a nearby CVS parking lot and then asked him if he had papers.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: The federal agents arrested petitioner, but failed to show him a warrant.

extracted.value: The federal agents arrested petitioner but failed to show him a warrant.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: Nor did the federal agents inform petitioner they were immigration officers authorized to make an arrest or the basis for the arrest.

extracted.value: The federal agents did not inform petitioner that they were immigration officers authorized to make an arrest or the basis for the arrest.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: Petitioner was initially transported to and held at the federal building at 300 North Los Angeles Street in B‑18.

extracted.value: Petitioner was initially transported to and held at the federal building at 300 North Los Angeles Street in B‑18.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: The facility was full and the people held there were told there was no food, water, or medicine.

extracted.value: The facility was full and the people held there were told there was no food, water, or medicine.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: Petitioner was transferred to Adelanto ICE Processing Center (“Adelanto”), where he remains.

extracted.value: Petitioner was transferred to Adelanto ICE Processing Center (“Adelanto”), where he remains.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: On June 20, 2025, petitioner Osorto, along with co-petitioners Vasquez Perdomo and Villegas Molina, initiated this action by filing a Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2241, naming as respondents: Kristi Noem, Secretary of Homeland Security; Pam Bondi, Attorney General; Immigration and Customs Enforcement; and Todd M. Lyons, Acting Los Angeles Field Office Director of ICE.

extracted.value: On June 20, 2025, petitioner Osorto, along with co-petitioners Vasquez Perdomo and Villegas Molina, filed a Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2241, naming respondents: Kristi Noem, Secretary of Homeland Security; Pam Bondi, Attorney General; Immigration and Customs Enforcement; and Todd M. Lyons, Acting ICE Officer Director.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: On July 21, 2025, petitioner Osorto filed the instant ex parte application for relief from immigration custody.

extracted.value: On July 21, 2025, petitioner Osorto filed the instant ex parte application for relief from immigration custody.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: On July 23, 2025, the immigration court denied the parties’ renewed motions for a bond hearing on the grounds that DHS failed to allege any new facts or explain how the immigration court would have jurisdiction.

extracted.value: On July 23, 2025, the immigration court denied the parties’ renewed motions for a bond hearing on the grounds that DHS failed to allege any new facts or explain how the immigration court would have jurisdiction.

evidence.source_document: Memorandum Opinion and Order Granting Petitioner Osorto's Ex Parte Application for Release from Immigration Custody
evidence.text: Petitioner had a blood pressure reading of 190 and is experiencing dizziness, headaches, confusion, and burned, peeling skin.

extracted.value: Petitioner had a blood pressure reading of 190 and experienced dizziness, headaches, confusion, and burned, peeling skin.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: On June 6, 2025, U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agents and officers were sent to join officers from the Enforcement and Removal Operations directorate of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to carry out “Operation At Large” in Los Angeles, California.

extracted.value: Operation At Large began on June 6, 2025, when U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agents and officers were sent to Los Angeles to conduct "Operation At Large".

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: contact teams … consist of three to five agents who contact individuals in public places such as streets, sidewalks, parking lots, or the publicly-accessible portions of businesses. Certain types of businesses, including carwashes, were selected for encounters because past experience demonstrated that they are likely to employ persons without legal documentation.

extracted.value: Contact teams that carried out the operation consist of three to five agents who target businesses such as carwashes to identify and detain individuals.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: During operations in Los Angeles, [federal] agents temporarily detained individuals, and made arrests for immigration violations and federal criminal statutes.

extracted.value: Agents detained individuals and made arrests for immigration violations and federal criminal statutes during Operation At Large.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: On the afternoon of June 12, he stepped onto the sidewalk outside of a tow yard in Montebello, California, where he saw agents carrying handguns… The agents forcefully pushed Gavidia up against the metal gated fence… The agent asked again, “What hospital were you born in?” Gavidia again explained that he did not know… The agents took Gavidia’s ID and his phone and kept his phone for 20 minutes. They never returned his ID.

extracted.value: Jason Brian Gavidia, a U.S. citizen, was stopped on June 12, 2025 at a tow yard in Montebello, where agents forced him, seized his ID and phone, and failed to return the ID.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: On June 9, 2025, masked agents arrived at the carwash in unmarked vehicles… The agent asked for ID, and Hernandez Viramontes gave him his California driver’s license. The agent asked Hernandez Viramontes where he was born… The agent grabbed his arm and escorted him to a silver SUV… The agents never identified themselves…

extracted.value: Jorge Luis Hernandez Viramontes, a dual U.S./Mexican citizen, was stopped on June 9, 2025 at a carwash in Whittier, where agents interrogated him, took his California driver’s license, and escorted him to a vehicle.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: On the morning of June 18, 2025, Vasquez Perdomo, Osorto, and Villegas Molina waited to be picked up for a construction job… Suddenly, four unmarked cars pulled up… The agents grabbed him, put his hands behind his back, and handcuffed him… The agents never identified themselves… The men put the plaintiffs in separate cars and drove them to a parking lot where they interrogated them further… The men never identified themselves…

extracted.value: Pedro Vasquez Perdomo, Carlos Osorto, and Isaac Villegas Molina were stopped on June 18, 2025 at a Metro bus stop in Pasadena, were handcuffed, and taken to a Los Angeles detention center.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: Angel is a U.S. citizen who identifies as Latino. Angel was walking to a community center with a coworker when two vehicles “pulled up to them suddenly.” One was a U.S. Customs and Border Patrol truck… The agent driving the truck asked Angel where he was born. Angel responded, “Simi Valley.” The agent then asked: “What hospital?” Angel provided the hospital’s name. The agent then turned to Angel’s coworker… The agents forced Angel to show him his Real ID…

extracted.value: Angel, a UFW member, was stopped by agents on a community center sidewalk, questioned about his birthplace, forced to show his ID, and was subjected to a physical seizure by agents.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: the district court found Plaintiffs ‘are likely to succeed in showing seizures requiring reasonable suspicion have occurred as part of Operation At Large’.

extracted.value: The district court found that plaintiffs are likely to succeed in showing that seizures requiring reasonable suspicion have occurred as part of Operation At Large.

evidence.source_document: Order (002)
evidence.text: The district court concluded that the challenged stops were based solely on the four enumerated factors: apparent race or ethnicity, speaking Spanish or English with an accent, presence at a particular location, and type of work.

extracted.value: The district court concluded that the challenged stops were based solely on the four enumerated factors: apparent race or ethnicity, speaking Spanish or English with an accent, presence at a particular location, and type of work.
